Document_Content: urn:contentItem:5XX9-GKP1-DYG0-93VF-00000-00<published>2020-01-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos and Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - All people missing in Victoria's deadly bushfires have been found safe, but authorities are still trying to rescue about 300 people stranded on a coastal holiday town.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   More than 1500 people have been taken out by defence helicopter and ship from Mallacoota, near the NSW border, which was cut off a week ago when fire raced through bush and into homes.<br/>   "We've got 300 people who didn't register for the ship first off, wanted to get on the aircraft, and now they smoked in," Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville told reporters in Melbourne.<br/>   "They've got a choice today to take up the offer of the boat, and people are being talked to today, or staying and hoping the smoke clears sometime in the next couple of days.<br/>   "But be assured we are absolutely doing everything we can, when we can to get in to both evacuate people out, but also to provide food, water, supplies and fuel, all of which was done to Mallacoota over the last couple of days."<br/>   Premier Daniel Andrews on Monday confirmed the four people missing on Sunday were accounted for and no one missing in the fires that have razed East Gippsland and the northeast.<br/>   He also announced a new and permanent government agency Bushfire Recovery Victoria, to be headed by former police chief commissioner Ken Lay to respond to the fires, with an initial $50 million in funding.<br/>   "It will coordinate allgovernment effort," he told reporters in Melbourne.<br/>   "Unlike the authority that was established in the wake of the February 2009 fires, this is not a time-limited or an authority that's about clean-up and recovery just for these bushfires.<br/>   "Because we're going to see longer fire seasons and we are going to see - we should just be honest about the fact - we're going to see more and more fires, more and more damage as each fire season comes."<br/>   Thick smoke blanketing Melbourne and regional Victoria is likely to hang around for days.<br/>   Authorities warn people should stay indoors as much as possible.<br/>   One million hectares has been burnt and there are 27 going fires across Victoria.<br/>   Rain has started to fall, but not across all fire-affected areas and not enough to douse the fires, and is creating new difficulties.<br/>   A Forest Fire Management vehicle flipped on a greasy road on Sunday because rain had not fallen in the area for so long, Mr Andrews said.<br/>   No one in the vehicle was seriously injured.<br/>   The fires have killedBuchan man Mick Roberts and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker.<br/>   The cooler weather has allowed military helicopters to deliver supplies to isolated communities and help with evacuations, reaching 13 communities on Sunday.<br/>   More than 3500 properties remain without power, with AusNet bringing in generators when possible and restoring the network when it is safe to do so.<br/>   All warnings now sit at a watch and act level.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XX9-GKP1-DYG0-93VF-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="481"/><timeReceived>2:13 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. flares</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A FIRE flared in a pine forest near Mt Gambier last night, 16 days after it was brought under control.</p><p>Smouldering bark chips reignited at Wandilo, where 1040ha of trees were burnt on February 19.</p><p> Country Fire Service volunteers were recalled to the site about 7.50 last night.</p><p> A CFS spokesman said it was not unusual for embers to flare up and the vast piles of bark would need to be closely monitored.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5TFK-1841-JD3N-51G6-00000-00Crews fire up for season2018-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Crews fire up for seasonBrittany Shanahan

FIRE trucks and equipment were tested as emergency services turned up the heat on their bushfire season preparations.

The Country Fire Authority was joined by Forest Fire Management and Nillumbik Council at Yarrambat Lake for a two-hour exercise last week to test gear and train new council staff on how trucks are used in different situations.

Crews from Arthurs Creek, Diamond Creek, Doreen, Mernda, Panton Hill and St Andrews practised pumping water from the lake into various brigade tankers, including the council's own fleet of tankers.

Mayor Peter Clarke said: "If needed, council's tankers are able to pump water from lakes, dams and fire hydrants, transferring it to a central staging area and making it easier and faster for CFA tankers to refill." "This is a great example of council, CFA and Forest Fire Management working together to understand our capabilities, share our processes and protocols, and unite our resources for the community."This week is Fire Action Week, with people urged to prepare their properties for bushfire season.

The Californian Governor, Mr George Deukmejian, declared a state of emergency yesterday for San Luis Obispo county, the third Californian county this month. Eight houses in San Luis Obispo were damaged or destroyed by a 9-metre wall of flames yesterday. Fires have destroyed more than 150 houses and killed three people in California to date. (AP)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5Y07-4Y51-DYG0-92KM-00000-00<published>2020-01-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 15 AAP - Thick smoke blanketing Melbourne, delaying flights at the city's airport, will clear as a cool change passes through but the accompanying thunderstorm and rain may hinder firefighting efforts.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Authorities on Wednesday confirmed a fifth death would be added to the Victorian bushfire toll and warned an upcoming cool change could bring more risks.<br/>   Smoke blowing in from the deadly bushfires still raging in East Gippsland and the northeast forced the closure of one of Melbourne Airport's runways on Wednesday, causing some delays, a spokesperson confirmed.<br/>   It is the second day of poor air quality for the city, with Ambulance Victoria receiving more than 100 calls during the morning from people with breathing problems, an increase of 75 per cent.<br/>   Racing Victoria has abandoned meets but tennis players at the Australian Open qualifiers will have to battle through delayed matches after complaining about the smoke on Tuesday.<br/>   A cool change is expected to pass through Melbourne between 4pm and 6pm, according to the Bureau of Meteorology, bringing with it up to 15mm of rain.<br/>   "Stay tuned for those dark, ominous clouds moving in from the north, because they could unleash heavy rainfall leading to flash flooding,"senior forecaster Kevin Parkyn told reporters.<br/>   Mr Parkyn said while the thunderstorms would clear the city smoke haze, it could create flash flooding and mudslides in fire-affected areas because of reduced vegetation.<br/>   There are 16 fires still burning across the state and more than 1.4 million hectares burnt.<br/>   The death toll from the fires has risen to five, after authorities confirmed the November 30 death of Forrest Fires Management contractorDavid Moresi, 69, near Gelantipy would be added to the toll.<br/>   "David wasa pillar of the community, a dedicated educator. He loved the bush and he inspired so many people to be in the great outdoors," Chief Fire Officer of Forest Fire Management Victoria Chris Hardman said.<br/>   He said Mr Moresi is survived by his wife, Judi, three children and many grandchildren - "the great bushmen of the future" whom he taught to shoot, fish and hunt.<br/>   The Australian Defence Force, meanwhile, has been involved in clearing fallen and badly burnt trees from across the Princes Highway - the main road between the East Gippsland and the NSW South Coast - as well as the only road out of Mallacoota.<br/>   Theydelivered the first drop of 13 bags of mail to the coastal town on Tuesday, as well as 12,000 litres of water to nearby Bairnsdale.<br/>   More than 1500 people were evacuated from Mallacoota on military vessels and aircraft after it wassuddenly cut off by bushfires and people sheltered on the beach more than two weeks ago.<br/>   It's Australia's largest peacetime humanitarian rescue mission since Cyclone Tracy and more have since left by a road convoy.<br/>   Overnight about 14 people had to seek shelter by the beach when fires flared, but this time at Tamboon.<br/>   There are 1500 firefighters battling the blazes, including 130 from overseas and another 140 international personnel will arrive later in January.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5Y07-4Y51-DYG0-92KM-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-14</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="520"/><timeReceived>1:22 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5Y07-FVW1-JC0X-K2RT-00000-00<published>2020-01-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 15 AAP - Thick smoke blanketing Melbourne, delaying flights at the city's airport, will clear as a cool change passes through but the accompanying thunderstorm and rain may hinder firefighting efforts.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Authorities on Wednesday confirmed a fifth death would be added to the Victorian bushfire toll and warned an upcoming cool change could bring more risks.<br/>   Smoke blowing in from the deadly bushfires still raging in East Gippsland and the northeast forced the closure of one of Melbourne Airport's runways on Wednesday, causing some delays, a spokesperson confirmed.<br/>   It is the second day of poor air quality for the city, with Ambulance Victoria receiving more than 100 calls during the morning from people with breathing problems, an increase of 75 per cent.<br/>   Racing Victoria has abandoned meets but tennis players at the Australian Open qualifiers will have to battle through delayed matches after complaining about the smoke on Tuesday.<br/>   A cool change is expected to pass through Melbourne between 4pm and 6pm, according to the Bureau of Meteorology, bringing with it up to 15mm of rain.<br/>   "Stay tuned for those dark, ominous clouds moving in from the north, because they could unleash heavy rainfall leading to flash flooding,"senior forecaster Kevin Parkyn told reporters.<br/>   Mr Parkyn said while the thunderstorms would clear the city smoke haze, it could create flash flooding and mudslides in fire-affected areas because of reduced vegetation.<br/>   There are 16 fires still burning across the state and more than 1.4 million hectares burnt.<br/>   The death toll from the fires has risen to five, after authorities confirmed the November 30 death of Forrest Fires Management contractorDavid Moresi, 69, near Gelantipy would be added to the toll.<br/>   "David wasa pillar of the community, a dedicated educator. He loved the bush and he inspired so many people to be in the great outdoors," Chief Fire Officer of Forest Fire Management Victoria Chris Hardman said.<br/>   He said Mr Moresi is survived by his wife, Judi, three children and many grandchildren - "the great bushmen of the future" whom he taught to shoot, fish and hunt.<br/>   The Australian Defence Force, meanwhile, has been involved in clearing fallen and badly burnt trees from across the Princes Highway - the main road between the East Gippsland and the NSW South Coast - as well as the only road out of Mallacoota.<br/>   Theydelivered the first drop of 13 bags of mail to the coastal town on Tuesday, as well as 12,000 litres of water to nearby Bairnsdale.<br/>   More than 1500 people were evacuated from Mallacoota on military vessels and aircraft after it wassuddenly cut off by bushfires and people sheltered on the beach more than two weeks ago.<br/>   It's Australia's largest peacetime humanitarian rescue mission since Cyclone Tracy and more have since left by a road convoy.<br/>   Overnight about 14 people had to seek shelter by the beach when fires flared, but this time at Tamboon.<br/>   There are 1500 firefighters battling the blazes, including 130 from overseas and another 140 international personnel will arrive later in January.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5Y07-FVW1-JC0X-K2RT-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-15</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="520"/><timeReceived>1:22 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5Y07-YXH1-JC0X-K2SX-00000-00<published>2020-01-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos and Ulises Uzquierdo<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 15 AAP - Melbourne has felt the full brunt of four seasons in one day, with flight-delaying smoke in the morning giving way to threats of flash flooding in the afternoon.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The smoke blowing in from the deadly bushfires still raging in East Gippsland caused the second day of poor air quality for the city, with the closure of a runway at Melbourne Airport and some flights delayed.<br/>   But the weather front that brought heavy rain to Melbourne late on Wednesday could mean more bushfire trouble.<br/>   The thunderstorm carried lightning that ignited fires in the Great Otway National Park and as the front moves across the state, authorities fear it could do the same in the fire-ravaged East Gippsland and northeast regions.<br/>   Ambulance Victoria received more than 100 calls during the morning from people with breathing problems, an increase of 75 per cent.<br/>   The cool change swept through Melbourne mid-afternoon and the temperature plummeted from the mid-30s to the low 20s.<br/>   While the storms cleared the smoke, there were warnings of flash flooding in Melbourne.<br/>   The Bureau of Meteorology issued a severe thunderstorm warning for many parts of the state, along with Melbourne.<br/>   The thunderstorm is expected to clear overnight in Melbourne, with a shower or two forecast for Thursday.<br/>   By 6pm on Wednesday, six 'Watch and Act' alerts remained in place for the fires that have devastated East Gippsland since November 21.<br/>   The death toll from the fires rose to five on Wednesday, after authorities confirmed the November 30 death of Forest Fires Management contractor David Moresi, 69, near Gelantipy would be added to it.<br/>   "David wasa pillar of the community, a dedicated educator. He loved the bush and he inspired so many people to be in the great outdoors," Chief Fire Officer of Forest Fire Management Victoria Chris Hardman said.<br/>   Mr Moresi is survived by his wife, Judi, three children and many grandchildren - "the great bushmen of the future" whom he taught to shoot, fish and hunt.<br/>   The Australian Defence Force, meanwhile, was involved in clearing fallen and badly burnt trees from across the Princes Highway - the main road between the East Gippsland and the NSW South Coast.<br/>   This road is also the only road out of Mallacoota, the town that became isolated in December.<br/>   More than 1500 people were evacuated from Mallacoota on military vessels and aircraft after it wassuddenly cut off by bushfires and people sheltered on the beach more than two weeks ago.<br/>   It's Australia's largest peacetime humanitarian rescue mission since Cyclone Tracy and more have since left by a road convoy.<br/>   This traumatic experience was relived by a small group of residents in a town cut-off by fire on Wednesday night.<br/>   The around 12 people that remained at Tamboon were forced to shelter on the beach after a blaze in Victoria's East Gippsland flared.<br/>   There are 1500 firefighters battling the blazes, including 130 from overseas and another 140 international personnel will arrive later in January.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5Y07-YXH1-JC0X-K2SX-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-15</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="510"/><timeReceived>6:50 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. Forest Fire Management Victoria has begun recruiting Project Firefighters for summer as well as new permanent Forest and Fire Operations Officers across central Victoria.

Project firefighter jobs will be located at Castlemaine, Inglewood, Cohuna, Echuca, Avoca, Bendigo, Heathcote, Maryborough, Rushworth and St Arnaud.

And Forest Fire Operations Officer jobs will be based in Castlemaine and Cohuna.

More info: www.ffm.vic.gov.au or call 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5TBV-6RD1-JD3N-53RK-00000-00Planned burns near Anglesea2018-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Planned burns near Anglesea

PLANNED burns have begun in the Otways District.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews began the spring planned burns near Anglesea on Tuesday, with about 30 firefighters carrying out a 110ha burn along Forest Rd, 5km north of the town.

"These operations will be the first in a series of planned burns in the Otway District to reduce bushfire fuel across spring," Forest Fire Management Victoria Otway District manager David Roberts said.

"We are expecting our opportunities for planned burns to be limited leading into summer, given the often windy and rapidly drying conditions experienced throughout spring.

"The burns we undertake this spring will be relatively small in size, but will be in strategically valuable locations, to ensure they are safe and secure.

"These burns will complement our larger autumn program, which is when the bulk of our planned burning activities take place.

"A key part of our strategic bushfire management planning is around reducing fuel loads in the eastern Otways."For the latest information about planned burns visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn.

urn:contentItem:5XX8-YNX1-DYG0-93TB-00000-00<published>2020-01-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer and Benita Kolovos<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - Thick smoke from bushfires is likely to blanket Melbourne for days, prompting a warning from authorities.<br/>   The air quality is at its worst in East Gippsland, as dozens of bushfires continue to burn in the region on Monday.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Environment Protection Authority has also recorded "very poor" air quality in Melbourne's metropolitan area, attributing the smoke to bushfires burning in the state as well as in NSW and Tasmania.<br/>   Chief environmental scientist Andrea Henwood urged people to take precautions to take precautions, saying the smoke will linger until Wednesday.<br/>   "Close everything up. Seal the doors. Now would be a good time to do that because this is going to persist for the rest of the day," Dr Henwood told reporters.<br/>   "If it persists into the next couple of days you want to have as much clean air as you can within your home."<br/>   Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton advised people with lung or heart conditions, the young and old, and pregnant women to stay indoors.<br/>   He said healthy people may also experience symptoms including eye, nose and throat irritation, coughing, sneezing and congestion.<br/>   For those severely impacted by the smoke, Dr Sutton said face masks were an option.<br/>   "They're not for everyone. They need to be fitted properly. If they're not fitted properly, they're not working," he said.<br/>   There are 31 fires burning across Victoria as of Monday morning, with 18 in eastern Gippsland and six in the northeast.<br/>   One million hectares has been burnt across Victoria.<br/>   Rain has started to fall, but not across all fire-affected areas and not enough to douse the fires, and is creating new difficulties.<br/>   "It does in fact create some other challenges in a strange way. We had a Forest Fire Management vehicle tip over yesterday, thankfully no one was seriously injured," Premier Daniel Andrews told 3AW on Monday.<br/>   Mr Andrews said the track the vehicle was travelling had been greasy because rain had not fallen there in such a long time.<br/>   "So it's better than it not raining but it's nowhere near enough for us to think this fire event's over," he said.<br/>   The deadly fires have killedBuchan man Mick Roberts and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker anddestroyed at least 110 properties and 220 outbuildings. Four people remain missing.<br/>   The cooler weather has allowed military helicopters to deliver supplies to isolated communities and help with evacuations, reaching 13 communities on Sunday.<br/>   They also rescued 406 people from Mallacoota and will continue to try and fly out a remaining 300 people who registered for evacuation. Navy ships brought out more than 1100 people on Saturday.<br/>   More than 3500 properties remain without power, with AusNet bringing in generators when possible and restoring the network when it is safe to do so.<br/>   All warnings now sit at a watch and act level.<br/>   The state government has announced a fund to support Victorian bushfire survivors, contributing $2 million.<br/>   Seventy-one firefighters from the US and Canada will arrive on Wednesday to help with firefighting efforts.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XX8-YNX1-DYG0-93TB-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="517"/><timeReceived>11:09 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Adds bushfire warning for the Adelaide Hills<br/>Tim Dornin<br/>   ADELAIDE, Jan 3 AAP - An emergency warning is in place for a bushfire burning in the Adelaide Hills as the Country Fire Service also battles a "virtually unstoppable" blaze on Kangaroo Island.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The Hills fire at Kersbrook was an immediate threat to lives and homes in the area and broke out late on Friday after a day of extreme conditions across the state.<br/>   The CFS said the forest fire was burning in a southeasterly direction towardsCromer and Forreston.<br/>   An emergency warning also remained in place for the Kangaroo Island fire which was burning freely through the Flinders Chase National Park after jumping containment lines.<br/>   By mid-afternoon, it had burnt through 14,000 hectares as it resisted efforts by about 150 firefighters to bring it under control.<br/>   Locals and tourists had been urged to leave the area with a luxury resort also evacuated, apart from a skeleton staff.<br/>   However, Country Fire Service chief officer Mark Jones said it was disappointing that some had not heeded warnings and had chosen to stay.<br/>   He said for them, it might now be too late and they should seek shelter.<br/>   Mr Jonessaid there were no confirmed reports of property losses or any injuries, but he said he wouldbe "astonished" if homes had not been destroyed.<br/>   A forecast wind shift later on Friday was expected to push the fire to the east and north, effectively creating a danger zone covering the entire western part of the island.<br/>   "The resources that are on the ground are having a good impact," Mr Jones said.<br/>   "But the conditions and the severity of the fire means that it's virtually unstoppable at the current time.<br/>   "The visibility is extremely poor, even for our aerial bombers, it's difficult for them to see the fire line where they wish to make the drop."<br/>   Mr Jones said another fire burning at Duncan on Kangaroo Island also breached containment lines but had since been brought back under greater control.<br/>   The escalating danger on the island came as SA endured a day of severe to extreme fire conditions with very high temperatures and rising winds across the state.<br/>   In the Adelaide Hills, where 25,000 hectares were blackened two weeks ago, a small fire in hay bales at Woodside was quickly contained.<br/>   And a fire burning on Eyre Peninsula was threatening to cut power to the area.<br/>   Department of Energy engineer Reinhard Struve said thick smoke could cause a transmission line flashover which would prompt the system to trip, cutting electricity supplies.<br/>    In such circumstances, Port Lincoln would be restored relatively quickly with backup generators but isolated properties were likely to be without power for some time.<br/>   The Bureau of Meteorology said the cool change moving across SA would reach Kangaroo Island by late afternoon and Adelaide by about 9pm.<br/>   The city had a top temperature of 41C ahead of the change, but conditions were forecast to be milder over the weekend with tops in the mid-20s.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4MGC-5PD0-TXDB-G30R-00000-00SA pine forest fire contained2006-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisSA pine forest fire contained

The South Australian Country Fire Service (CFS) says it has contained a large bushfire that is burning in a pine forest to the west of Mt Gambier in the state's south-east.

The fire has destroyed about 200 hectares of pine forest near Tantanoola, and there was concern that it was burning towards Glencoe and Mount Gambier.

But the CFS says it contained the blaze around 8:00pm ACDT.

Up to 250 firefighters are now being rested as strike teams from other areas keep the blaze under control.

At least two fire-bombing aircraft will again be used in the morning.

In the Riverland, over 100 firefighters are still battling a blaze near Overland Corner that has been burning since Monday.

So far it has burnt over 100 000 hectares of bushland, but no properties are being threatened.

urn:contentItem:5RYT-DDY1-JD34-V3R5-00000-00Planned burn-offs in Hume region to follow weekend rainfall2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisPlanned burn-offs in Hume region to follow weekend rainfallJodie Bruton

PLANNED burn-offs in the Hume region will start in the coming days after the weekend rain.

Forest Fire Management Victoria, which includes Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Parks Victoria, VicForests and Melbourne Water, is preparing to deliver the 2018 planned burn program.

The Autumn Planned Burning Program will be delivered across the four districts within Hume region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria works closely with the Bureau of Meteorology on planning burns.

This year Hume Region will issue the Planned Burning Weekly Outlook on Mondays and a daily notification at 5pm.

The weekly outlook will provide a progress update on the planned burning program, potential burning opportunities for the coming week, smoke impact areas and web links to useful sites.

urn:contentItem:4MKV-VFM0-TX5M-42W6-00000-00Timber workers join forest-fire fight2006-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Timber workers join forest-fire fight

POWELLTOWN timber contractors took $4 million worth of dozers, excavators and skidders to help fight forest fires around Woods Point last week.

Victorian manager of Timber Communities Australia Scott Gentle said three contractors, Ricky Green, David Silvester and Joe Ward, all from Powelltown, led a convoy under a police escort to the fire ground last Monday.

''Dozens of timber workers have already put their lives and heavy equipment on the fire line helping the firefighters to slow the fires' path,'' Mr Gentle said. ''People forget that timber workers volunteer their equipment and labour during times of crisis like this.''

He said the workers knew the bush well and were skilled operators.

urn:contentItem:5RVK-S051-F0J6-J2GS-00000-00Wood collection restrictions2018-03-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Wood collection restrictionsBen Hopkins

Forest Fire Management Victoria is reminding firewood collectors to check the regulations before going out this season.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's acting Grampians regional manager forest and fire operations, Taina Scott warned collectors about the possibility for smaller return when they travel out.

Premium wood supplies in particular are at a current shortage, meaning those traveling distances to get their hands such woods like red gum may be disappointed.

"The felling of any trees for firewood by members of the public is strictly prohibited, and we also remind firewood collectors to stay within collection limits," Mrs Scott said.

People are urged to report the illegal sale of firewood or any unauthorised activity to 136 186, or call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5XB0-M021-F0J6-J2JG-00000-00Planned burn for kimbolton2019-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Planned burn for kimboltonChris Pedler

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA will carry out a planned burn in the Kimbolton State Forest on Tuesday and Wednesday.

Smoke may be visible from Kimbolton, Eppalock, Myrtle Creek and Mosquito Creek during the burn.

The fuel-reduction burn will be focused on the Kimbolton-Airport Track area with smoke tipped to be visible until Saturday. Drivers are advised to take care and obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire crews near the burn. Access to walking tracks and camp sites may be limited.

urn:contentItem:5WXX-C9J1-JD34-V1PH-00000-00Firewood collection set to open2019-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisFirewood collection set to openBlair Thomson

The spring firewood collection season will open in Victoria tomorrow.

People will be able to collect wood from designated areas until the end of November.

Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman Aaron Kennedy said it was important people only took wood from designated areas.

People can collect up to two cubic metres of firewood each day, and up to 16 cubic metres per household each year.

He said felling trees was strictly forbidden, with patrols in place.

urn:contentItem:5S72-GKT1-F0J6-J0BV-00000-00Three planned burns set to take place from Tuesday2018-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisThree planned burns set to take place from Tuesday

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan to carry out three planned burns in the Murray Goldfields district from tomorrow, weather permitting.

They included 291 hectares 5 kilometres east of Bendigo in the Bendigo Regional Park.

A fuel reduction burn was also planned at the Heathcote-Dargile Track, 6 kilometres north of Heathcote in the Heathcote Graytown National Park.

A traditional burn of 1.8 hectares was planned for the Gunbower forest, 8.5 kilometres north of Cohuna.

Forest Fire Victoria said the burns should be completed between Tuesday and Friday.

Smoke may be visible in Bendigo, Junortoun, Strathfieldsaye, Heathcote, Graytown and Cohuna.

If you experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024

If you would like any further information, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5X18-29Y1-JD34-V4M8-00000-00Minimising the risks of bushfire2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Minimising the risks of bushfire

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria are introducing fire restrictions for East Gippsland Shire, starting from 1am on Monday, September 23 and continuing until May 1, 2020 unless stated otherwise.

CFA's Assistant Chief Officer South East, Trevor Owen and FFMVic Deputy Chief Officer, Beth Roberts said that restrictions are being enforced early again in East Gippsland to minimise the risk of grass and bushfires being started by private burn-offs and escaped campfires in the current dry conditions.

urn:contentItem:5XVP-KJN1-F0J6-J17T-00000-00Firefighters contain Upper Murray blaze to four hectares2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Firefighters contain Upper Murray blaze to four hectares

Firefighters contained a bushfire in the Upper Murray on Saturday afternoon.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said the four hectare blaze began mid-morning in the Wabba Wilderness Park area, about 35 kilometres south west of Corryong.

The authority announced at 2.44pm the fire had been contained, although firefighters were still patrolling and blacking out.

Heavy machinery also continued to reinforce containment lines.

The fire did not threaten any Upper Murray communities.

urn:contentItem:7VBF-17V0-Y9Y8-S50K-00000-00Crews work to contain state forest fire2009-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisCrews work to contain state forest fire

Fire crews will continue to battle a bushfire near Bright, in north-eastern Victoria, that is believed to been have started by a campfire.

The fire is burning in state forest about 13 kilometres from the town, and was reported yesterday afternoon.

It has so far burnt five hectares of bushland and no private property is under threat.

Department of Sustainability and Environment duty fire officer Alan Dobson says the blaze should be contained today with the help of water bombing aircraft and ground crews.

"It is on the end of summer but this is just indicative of what can happen when fires are left," he said.

"We haven't had any rain, the bush is still dry, hopefully we'll get rain before Easter and things will be a bit easier then."

urn:contentItem:5MXH-C811-JD3N-53CY-00000-00Burns are on the way in Otways2017-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Burns are on the way in Otways

DON'T be too alarmed if you see water bombers and fire trucks in the Otways over the coming weeks, as Forest Fire Management Victoria crews are working on planned burns in the region.

Weather permitting, the burns will continue until the end of April. Forest Fire Management Victoria Otway district manager David Rourke said the program would kick off with small grassland burns near Breamlea and Casey.

"These will be followed by a series of significant burns around Lorne, the largest of which will be around 1200ha. There will also be significant planned burns further inland, around Forrest and Gellibrand," he said.

Crews will be using fire tankers, bulldozers, helicopters and water bombers during the operation.

Roadside electronic signs will be posted along major roads in the area.Stay up to date on planned burns by searching the Forest Fire Management Victoria website at delwp.vic.gov.au/ffmvic/planned-burns or calling 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:7V06-K1C1-2RG7-20YP-00000-00Boswell calls for overhaul of forest fire management2009-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisBoswell calls for overhaul of forest fire management

Nationals Senator Ron Boswell says there needs to be an urgent overhaul of how national parks and forest reserves are set up and managed.

He says not enough is done to reduce the fire risk in bushland.

"I'm not blaming anyone for this, I just think we need to look at some areas we turn into parks and then can't defend them," he said.

"All of a sudden you get something [that] goes through them and you get a blast of hot temperature and hot air and the consequences - a huge number of people are dead. We really just can't go on like this."

urn:contentItem:5PTJ-8X11-F0J6-J07C-00000-00Fighting fires together across state borders2017-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisFighting fires together across state borders

Bushfires don't respect boundaries and fires that start close to the Victorian/NSW border in the far east of the region have potential to threaten communities, infrastructure and assets in both states.

The agreement between emergency response agencies addresses the issues and complexities of the management of cross-border fires.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Chris Stephenson said: "We met in Lakes Entrance on Wednesday, to review and update our agreement and to prepare for the season ahead.

Agencies include NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service, Forestry Corporation of NSW, NSW Rural Fire Service, Police, Forest Fire Management and CFA.

urn:contentItem:5PTJ-8X11-F0J6-J1C6-00000-00Fighting fires together across state borders2017-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisFighting fires together across state borders

Bushfires don't respect boundaries and fires that start close to the Victorian/NSW border in the far east of the region have potential to threaten communities, infrastructure and assets in both states.

The agreement between emergency response agencies addresses the issues and complexities of the management of cross-border fires.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Chris Stephenson said: "We met in Lakes Entrance on Wednesday, to review and update our agreement and to prepare for the season ahead.

Agencies include NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service, Forestry Corporation of NSW, NSW Rural Fire Service, Police, Forest Fire Management and CFA.

urn:contentItem:5XYK-9P51-DYG0-9557-00000-00<published>2020-01-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Karen Sweeney<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 12 AAP - A man killed by a falling tree while battling a blaze in the state?s alpine region was a 40-year veteran firefighter.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Bill Slade, 60, was fighting fires with Parks Victoria near Omeo when he died on Saturday.<br/>   The married father of two from Wonthaggi has been remembered as one of the longest serving, most experienced and fittest firefighters.<br/>   ?This is a significant loss for the Forest Fire Management Victoria family and the community as a whole,? FFMV boss Chris Hardman said Sunday morning.<br/>   Mr Slade was on a taskforce working at the fire?s edge at Anglers Rest.<br/>   ?Although we do have enormous experience in identifying hazardous trees, sometimes these tree failures can?t be predicted,? Mr Hardman said.<br/>   ?It would have been a traumatic experience for everybody on that taskforce.?<br/>   Mr Slade had worked on major fire incidents in the past including the Ash Wednesday bushfires.<br/>   His 40 years service was recognised in a presentation by Parks Victoria chief Matt Jackson in November.<br/>   He said it was a privilege to honour Mr Slade?s career and recognise the legacy he has left, as both a firefighter and a mentor to the community - a legacy which will continue for years to come.<br/>   ?Bill was a much loved colleague, friend and member of the Wonthaggi community. He?ll be sorely by Parks Victoria,? he said.<br/>   Mr Slade?s death follows the death of fellow FFMV firefighter Mat Kavanagh, 43, died on duty when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.<br/>   Mr Hardman said despite the now two deaths firefighters would continue to be deployed.<br/>   ?We have to be out there ... it?s a long time before the risks around these fires are over,? he said.<br/>   They?ll be out in the field until late February or March, or possibly beyond.<br/>   ?I think we need to be really clear unless we get really significant rains ... 100-150mm of rain we?re going to be in this for the long haul,? he said.<br/>   Victoria Police and Worksafe are investigating Mr Slade?s death.<br/>   Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner Andrew Crisp said benign conditions are forecast in the coming days, including thunderstorms expected to bring rain.<br/>   An emergency warning has remained constant for a fire near Mount Buffalo and it?s strongly suggested people leave toward Porepunkah, he said.<br/>   ?Even though we?ve got fairly benign weather conditions, this is yet another reminder where we?ve got fairly fairly active fire out there that people need to stay across conditions in their local area,? Mr Crisp said.<br/>   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville on Saturday said relieving exhausted emergency services workers was also a priority.<br/>   "People are very fatigued, that is the case with communities but also the case with our emergency service personnel, they are very exhausted and we need to be able to rotate in and out people," she said.<br/>   "We have got a chance to do that whilst we are also still doing a lot of the planning, a lot of the work that we can do to try and minimise the future impact of these fires."<br/>   More than 1.3 million hectares have been razed since November 21, while 286 homes and 400 other buildings have been damaged.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XYK-9P51-DYG0-9557-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-11</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="531"/><timeReceived>11:26 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5M1S-BNF1-F0J6-J3PN-00000-00Services meet to talk fire season2016-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisServices meet to talk fire seasonSiobhan Calafiore

Forest Fire Management Victoria held its 27th annual Grampians Fire Conference last week as emergency services prepare for the upcoming bushfire season.

One hundred representatives from Forest Fire Management Victoria, CFA, Victoria Police, local government, water authorities and other emergency management partners attended.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said the conference was an opportunity to focus on how services were working together to plan and deliver fire management.

"Teamwork between emergency management agencies and private landholders will be vital for the coming fire season," he said.

"We also reviewed how bushfire planning and operations have evolved over the last ten years, particularly since the Grampians Mount Lubra fire of January 2006."

He said it was especially important for visitors to the area to always be aware of the conditions and pay attention to campfire regulations.

urn:contentItem:5XX9-D9F1-JC0X-K3RV-00000-00<published>2020-01-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:56:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Benita Kolovos and Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Jan 6 AAP - All people missing in Victoria's deadly bushfires have been found safe, but at least 200 homes have been destroyed.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Premier Daniel Andrews on Monday confirmed the four people missing on Sunday were accounted for and no one was listed as missing in the fires that have razed East Gippsland and the northeast.<br/>   He also announced a new and permanent $50 million government agency Bushfire Recovery Victoria, to be headed by former police chief commissioner Ken Lay to respond to the fires.<br/>   "It will coordinate allgovernment effort," he told reporters in Melbourne.<br/>   "Unlike the authority that was established in the wake of the February 2009 fires, this is not a time-limited or an authority that's about clean-up and recovery just for these bushfires.<br/>   "Because we're going to see longer fire seasons and we are going to see - we should just be honest about the fact - we're going to see more and more fires, more and more damage as each fire season comes."<br/>   Thick smoke from bushfires is likely to blanket Melbourne for days, prompting a warning from authorities.<br/>   The air quality is at its worst in East Gippsland, where dozens of bushfires continue to burn on Monday.<br/>   The Environment Protection Authority has also recorded "very poor" air quality in Melbourne's metropolitan area, attributing the smoke to bushfires burning in the state as well as in NSW and Tasmania.<br/>   Chief environmental scientist Andrea Henwood urged people to take precautions, saying the smoke will linger until Wednesday.<br/>   "Close everything up. Seal the doors. Now would be a good time to do that because this is going to persist for the rest of the day," Dr Henwood told reporters.<br/>   Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton advised people with lung or heart conditions, the young and old, and pregnant women to stay indoors.<br/>   He said healthy people may also experience symptoms including eye, nose and throat irritation, coughing, sneezing and congestion.<br/>   There are 31 fires burning across Victoria as of Monday morning, with 18 in eastern Gippsland and six in the northeast.<br/>   One million hectares has been burnt across Victoria.<br/>   Rain has started to fall, but not across all fire-affected areas and not enough to douse the fires, and is creating new difficulties.<br/>   A Forest Fire Management vehicle flipped on a greasy road on Sunday because rain had not fallen in the area for so long, Mr Andrews said.<br/>   No one in the vehicle was seriously injured.<br/>   The deadly fires have killedBuchan man Mick Roberts and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker.<br/>   The cooler weather has allowed military helicopters to deliver supplies to isolated communities and help with evacuations, reaching 13 communities on Sunday.<br/>   They also rescued 406 people from Mallacoota but attempts to fly out another 300 on Monday were stalled because of the smoke. Navy ships brought out more than 1100 people on Saturday.<br/>   More than 3500 properties remain without power, with AusNet bringing in generators when possible and restoring the network when it is safe to do so.<br/>   All warnings now sit at a watch and act level.<br/>   The state government has announced a fund to support Victorian bushfire survivors, contributing $2 million.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2020</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XX9-D9F1-JC0X-K3RV-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-01-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="540"/><timeReceived>1:32 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2020 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5S72-GKT1-F0J6-J0CM-00000-00Three planned burns set to take place from Tuesday2018-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Three planned burns set to take place from Tuesday

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan to carry out three planned burns in the Murray Goldfields district from tomorrow, weather permitting.

They included 291 hectares 5 kilometres east of Bendigo in the Bendigo Regional Park.

A fuel reduction burn was also planned at the Heathcote-Dargile Track, 6 kilometres north of Heathcote in the Heathcote Graytown National Park.

A traditional burn of 1.8 hectares was planned for the Gunbower forest, 8.5 kilometres north of Cohuna.

Forest Fire Victoria said the burns should be completed between Tuesday and Friday.

Smoke may be visible in Bendigo, Junortoun, Strathfieldsaye, Heathcote, Graytown and Cohuna.

If you experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024

If you would like any further information, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5SKR-1SM1-F0J6-J38N-00000-00Firewood collection season to end2018-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisFirewood collection season to end

The autumn 2018 firewood collection season will close statewide on June 30.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Acting Fire Control Officer Peter Kambouris said from July 1 all designated firewood collection area will be closed during the winter period.

"It will be illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the start of the spring firewood collection season," he said.

"Firewood collection may already have ceased in some parts of the state where supplies are exhausted or where rainfall or flooding has affected track conditions making collection unsafe.

"The public will be able to start collecting firewood again from designated firewood collection areas from September 1, pending suitable conditions."

Firewood collected at designated sites is for personal use only and cannot be sold.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff will be patrolling parks, forests and reserves to ensure people are doing the right thing.

People not doing the right thing can be fined on the spot around $622 and for offences that go to court, a person may be liable for fines up to $7773, one-year imprisonment, or both.

trees in the state's South-East yesterday.</p><p>The blaze, which was reported to the Country Fire Service about 4.20pm, started in a four-year-old pine plantation 1km north of Naracoorte.</p><p> It was contained in 15 minutes by five CFS crews.</p><p> The damage was estimated at about $10,000 because some burnt trees may not recover.</p><p> The value of the trees saved was about urn:contentItem:7VWJ-YB01-2RG7-350J-00000-00Rain fails to dampen Otway Forest fire risk2009-06-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisRain fails to dampen Otway Forest fire risk

The Otway Ranges Environment Network predicts this week's rainfall will not reduce the bushfire risk in the Otway Forest this coming summer.

Since Sunday morning, more than 55 millimetres of rain has been recorded in the Otways, in south-west Victoria.

The Environment Network's Roger Hardley says the forest is still a fire-risk after six years of drought.

He says even with improved rainfall, the forest will still be prone to fire this summer if there are high temperatures.

"As an accumulation of rain over the winter and the spring, it certainly helps in a summer period," he said.

"But even in a situation in the summer when the forest was relatively damp, if these other attendant risks are present, she'll go up."

urn:contentItem:5M1S-BNF1-F0J6-J3S3-00000-00Services meet to talk fire season2016-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Services meet to talk fire seasonSiobhan Calafiore

Forest Fire Management Victoria held its 27th annual Grampians Fire Conference last week as emergency services prepare for the upcoming bushfire season.

One hundred representatives from Forest Fire Management Victoria, CFA, Victoria Police, local government, water authorities and other emergency management partners attended.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said the conference was an opportunity to focus on how services were working together to plan and deliver fire management.

"Teamwork between emergency management agencies and private landholders will be vital for the coming fire season," he said.

"We also reviewed how bushfire planning and operations have evolved over the last ten years, particularly since the Grampians Mount Lubra fire of January 2006."

He said it was especially important for visitors to the area to always be aware of the conditions and pay attention to campfire regulations.

urn:contentItem:5R5M-F961-JD34-V3BP-00000-00Bushfire risk reduction works continue throughout central Victoria2017-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Bushfire risk reduction works continue throughout central Victoria

Bushfire risk reduction works are continuing across central Victoria after the completion of spring planned burns.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews undertook 12 planned burns from mid-October in areas such as Maiden Gully, St Arnaud, Heathcote, Tarnagulla, Maryborough and Newstead.

Now, they are continuing their efforts with slashing and mowing around towns in a bid to reduce the bushfire risk in local communities.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields District acting manager Simon Brown said crews had completed about 1600 hectares of mechanical works in central Victoria at 700 different parks, forests and reserves since late spring.

"We slash, mulch and mow on Crown land to reduce fire risk and clear tracks to ensure safe access to the bush for firefighters during fire season," he said.

urn:contentItem:5R1S-W921-F0J6-J1VX-00000-00Lightning strike sparks blaze ahead of dangerous fire season2017-11-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisLightning strike sparks blaze ahead of dangerous fire season

A lightning strike sparked a blaze in the Lerderderg Gorge this week in a sign that the fire season has begun, authorities say.

The warning comes as the CFA, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Ballarat City Council met recently to discuss the start of the fire danger period, which begins today.

"We saw a number of lightning fires start across the state last Thursday with storms that moved through, one of which is in the Lerderderg," Ballarat-based Forest Fire Management Victoria manager Jasmine Filmer said. "We have crews on it, no issues are anticipated, but it indicates summer is on the way."

Once the fire danger period has been declared, fire restrictions come into force, meaning Ballarat residents cannot light a fire in the open air without a permit.

urn:contentItem:5M79-KMG1-JD34-V2PF-00000-00Fresh tracks winding back to old forest2016-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisLIFEPg. 19Fresh tracks winding back to old forest

A MAJOR upgrade to mountain bike trails in the Stanley State Forest is complete.

A joint project between the Yackandandah community, Indigo Shire Council and Forest Fire Management Victoria, the works were done over 12 months.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's District Manager - Ovens, Jarrod Hayse, said Yack Tracks Inc, a community-based group, had accessed funding, approvals and support from volunteers to upgrade the facilities.

"Informal mountain bike trails have existed in the Stanley State Forest for a decade or more but now an official network exists for all to enjoy," he said.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria refurbished the picnic area and upgraded signage at the site."

Yack Tracks Inc member James Lacey said 50 kilometres of purpose-built single track now existed for riders with many trails featuring remnants of the region's historic gold mining days.

"We have created four coloured loop trails which cater for riders of all abilities," he said.

For a map visit www.exploreyackandandah.com.au.

urn:contentItem:5PXC-F0V1-F0J6-J02N-00000-00â€‹Training for new firefighters2017-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15â€‹Training for new firefightersAnthony Piovesan

UP TO 28 of Forest Fire Management Victoria's newest firefighters have undergone a tough but informative training course at St Arnaud last week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's project firefighter co-ordinator Geoff Tyers said the General Fire Fighter course discussed fire behaviour, fire suppression, planned burning, safety and survival techniques.

"The firefighting course is a good mix of classroom- and field-based activities to get our recruits up to speed with the demands of the fire ground and the varied role of a firefighter," he said.

"The trainees will also conduct a fire event allowing them to practise the theory learned in the classroom.

"It is predicted to be an above-average fire season this year and these project firefighters are very much needed."
